block.p: A slower pace for economic reform in the Soviet Union was endorsed by President Gorbachev in a compromise program for dismantling the state's economic monopoly he sent to the Soviet Parliament.
A slower pace for economic reform in the Soviet Union was endorsed by President Gorbachev in a compromise program for dismantling the state's economic monopoly he sent to the Soviet Parliament.
A slower pace for economic reform in the Soviet Union was endorsed by President Gorbachev in a compromise program for dismantling the state's economic monopoly he sent to the Soviet Parliament.

Iraq wants a compromise settlement to the Kuwaiti crisis, but Washington considers the terms unacceptable and continues to insist that Iraq withdraw before any talks begin, Secretary of State Baker said.
News analysis: Saddam Hussein's seesaw diplomacy

Are the sanctions on Iraq working? An unexpected bounty of fruit, vegetables and canned goods in the country has diplomats concerned it will be many months before shortages begin to put pressure on Saddam Hussein.
Japan may send troops to the gulf in the country's first military foray abroad since World War II. But the plan, approved by the Cabinet, has run into opposition at home and among Japan's neighbors.
Tokyo Journal: A house is wishful thinking
Iraq is executing Kuwaiti prisoners in the presence of their families in what appears to be a new round of terror, report Kuwaiti witnesses who have managed to leave their country in recent days.
U.S. urging U.N. chief to quickly send his inquiry team to Israel
Jerusalem mayor splits with Israel on inquiry

The leaders of the two Koreas formally began a second round of negotiations to reduce tensions as South Koreans cautioned against expecting a breakthrough on the military and political issues dividing them.
Afghan guerrillas occupy a second provincial capital
An outspoken hard-liner in China, Wang Zen, the 82-year-old Vice President, is the target of some of the most bitter invective that is muttered quietly among young Chinese.
Administration wants to dilute El Salvador aid cut
Brazil won't sign atom pact but plans curbs, aide says
Unwanted, foreign workers are leaving eastern Germany
Joe Slovo, an old Marxist, has hopes now for South Africa
Damage from global warming could come sooner
Three U.S. professors win Nobel Prize in Economic Science

A new Democratic budget plan that would sharply raise the income taxes on the wealthy was approved by the House of Representatives. The vote came 11 days after it rejected the compromise struck by President Bush and Congressional leaders.
Senate passes rights bill but can't override threatened veto

George Bush is playing the outsider as he campaigns in his first midterm Congressional elections. His message during a trip across America's midsection: it is us against them, the Democrats in Congress.
Campaign trail: Trapped on Hill, Democrats fight by TV

Washington at Work: Bob Dole is fiercely proud of being pro. It shows in his careful, and correct, answers to questions about his role as Senate minority leader and his relations with the man who ended his chance at the White House, George Bush.

The quality of hospital care for the elderly has not been diminished by measures to limit Federal health care costs, a comprehensive national study has found. But more patients are being discharged in a medically unstable condition.
The obscenity trial of 2 Live Crew, the rap music group, began in Florida, and the songs that the prosecution portrayed as criminal were praised by the defense as provocative but harmless.

Destruction from the earthquake that rocked Northern California a year ago today is still evident in downtown Santa Cruz. But many say the physical ruins belie the real progress made toward rebuilding the city.
Maine asks U.S. to deny license to dam owners
Kansas Journal: Russians and Americans bury an era
''Baby boomers'' donate more, a survey says
Census put some houses where they do not exist
Gov. Dukakis of Massachusetts has retained an uncanny equilibrium, even after his defeat as Presidential nominee, the erosion of his popularity at home and the personal problems of his wife Kitty.

Mayor Dinkins ordered deep cuts of more than $1 billion in programs and services from the budgets of city agencies to help close budget gaps. Schools, the City University, public hospitals and the Fire Department would be spared to some degree.
Labor talks begin with charges of meddling

New York State is running a deficit of almost $250 million for the first half of the fiscal year, providing the first hard evidence of how far the state's fiscal fortunes may be sliding. Next year the gap could be as high as $3 billion.

Is the cheese advertising the man? Or is the man advertising the cheese? Whatever the answer, George Yancey Jr., a candidate for lieutenant governor and president of Heluva Good Cheese, is campaigning hard with an anti-Cuomo message.

Criminal charges can be filed against employers if they injure their employees at work, New York State's highest court ruled. The ruling said employers can face charges like murder and assault for failing to maintain safe workplaces.

The ooze of Oil City in Syracuse may be reborn into a huge development of parks, condominiums and a mall soaring to a height of about 17 stories. But some are uncertain about the project on a waste site that others see as the city's salvation.
Power officials from New York State and New England have become reluctant participants in a dispute over whether a Canadian utility should expand its generating capacity.
Agency reports little oversight of adult homes
Tests show no radiation leak at Indian Point
Third chess game is a draw after early fireworks
Cold day? Warm stew, hot debate
Learning to make dimes into millions
Boris B. Piotrovsky, director of the Hermitage in Leningrad
Not like old times for Stewart
Camera class puts life of homeless in focus
Holes in the fish safety net
Michael Y. Sokolove: Charlie Hustle - only human
John Budris: To Oslo, via Vilnius
